quiz.title: Unit 12: AP Microeconomics (Quiz 8)
quiz.subtitle: Taste Shifts, Expectations, and Inferior Goods
quiz.subject: AP Microeconomics
quiz.topic: Demand/Supply Shifts, Future Expectations, Income Elasticity

questions.question: Suppose consumer tastes shift toward the consumption of apples. Which of the following statements is an accurate description of the impact of this event on the market for apples?
options: There is an increase in the quantity demanded of apples along the demand curve and in the supply for apples.
There is an increase in the demand and supply of apples.
There is an increase in the demand for apples and a decrease in the supply of apples.
There is a decrease in the quantity demanded of apples along the demand curve and an increase in the supply for apples.
There is an increase in the demand for apples and an increase in the quantity supplied of apples along the supply curve.
questions.explanation: Increased taste for apples shifts demand right. Higher demand raises price, which increases quantity supplied (movement along supply curve). Supply does not shift unless a supply determinant changes.

questions.question: Suppose both buyers and sellers of wheat expect the price of wheat to rise in the near future. What would we expect to happen to the equilibrium price and quantity in the market for wheat today?
options: The impact on both price and quantity is ambiguous.
Price will decrease; quantity is ambiguous.
Price will increase; quantity will decrease.
Price will increase; quantity is ambiguous.
Price will increase; quantity will increase.
questions.explanation: Buyers expect higher future prices → demand increases today (shift right). Sellers expect higher future prices → supply decreases today (shift left). Both shifts increase price today. Quantity depends on relative shift magnitudes, so quantity change is ambiguous.

questions.question: An inferior good is one for which an increase in income causes a(n)
options: decrease in supply.
increase in demand.
increase in supply.
decrease in demand.
questions.explanation: Inferior good: demand decreases when income rises (negative income elasticity). Supply is not directly affected by changes in consumer income.

questions.question: Floor-Mart is one of many firms hiring workers in a perfectly competitive labor market. If Floor-Mart's demand for labor increases, how will this impact the number of workers hired by Floor-Mart and the equilibrium wage in this labor market.
options: The firm will hire fewer workers and the equilibrium wage will increase.
The firm will hire the same number of workers and the equilibrium wage will increase.
The firm will hire the same number of workers and the equilibrium wage will decrease.
The firm will hire more workers and the equilibrium wage will increase.
The firm will hire more workers and the equilibrium wage will remain the same.
questions.explanation: In a perfectly competitive labor market, a single firm’s demand increase does not affect market wage. The firm is a wage taker, so wage unchanged; firm hires more workers at that wage along its MRP curve.

questions.question: Assume the marginal social cost of the last unit of Iocane Powder provided is greater than the marginal social benefit. Which of the following can be used to achieve a more efficient outcome in the market for Iocane Powder?
options: A per-unit subsidy for Iocane Powder
A lump-sum subsidy for Iocane Powder
A per-unit tax for Iocane Powder
A lump-sum tax for Iocane Powder
Perfect price discrimination
questions.explanation: MSC > MSB → overproduction relative to social optimum. A per-unit tax raises private cost, reducing quantity toward socially optimal level.

questions.question: How would making a country's income tax more progressive affect the income inequality of its citizens?
options: It would increase income inequality
It would decrease income inequality
It would not affect income inequality
It would increase the wage difference between men and women
It would not affect the wage difference between men and women
questions.explanation: Progressive tax takes a larger percentage from higher incomes, reducing after-tax income inequality.

questions.question: When consumption of a good generates a positive externality, which of the following must be true at the market equilibrium?
options: Marginal social benefit is less than marginal private cost.
Marginal social benefit is greater than marginal private benefit.
Marginal social cost is greater than marginal social benefit.
Marginal social cost is less than marginal private benefit.
Marginal social cost is equal to marginal external benefit.
questions.explanation: Positive externality: MSB = MPB + external benefit → MSB > MPB at market equilibrium (where MPB = MPC).

questions.question: National defense is an example of a public good because
options: it requires tax revenues to fund any production
one person’s use of it will decrease another person’s ability to use it
it is nonexcludable and nonrival
the private market typically produces the socially efficient level of output
the public is protected from invasion
questions.explanation: Public goods are defined by non-excludability and non-rivalry in consumption.

questions.question: The amount of product Z that must be forgone in order to obtain some amount of product Y is called
options: factor payments
opportunity cost
marginal product
income effect
substitution effect
questions.explanation: Opportunity cost is the value of the next best alternative forgone.

questions.question: Which of the following is necessary in a well-functioning capitalist economy but not in a command economy?
options: Centralized decision making
Scarcity of resources
Monopolies
Protection of property rights
Positive externalities
questions.explanation: Capitalism relies on private property rights; command economies rely on state ownership and planning.

questions.question: If an unusually cold summer destroyed a large portion of the bee population, the equilibrium price and quantity of honey produced by bees will most likely change in which of the following ways?
options: Price Increase, Quantity Increase
Price Increase, Quantity Decrease
Price Increase, Quantity No change
Price Decrease, Quantity Decrease
Price No change, Quantity Decrease
questions.explanation: Fewer bees reduce honey supply (left shift) → price increases, quantity decreases.

questions.question: If the demand for insulin is price inelastic, a 5 percent increase in the price of insulin will
options: have no effect on the total revenue of insulin producers
increase the total revenue of insulin producers
decrease the total revenue of insulin producers
decrease the total spending on insulin by consumers
cause the demand for insulin to be less elastic
questions.explanation: Inelastic demand: price increase → small drop in quantity → total revenue rises.

questions.question: Which of the following would shift the short-run supply curve for strawberries?
options: A decrease in the consumption of strawberries
An increase in the price of strawberries
A strike by all farmworkers
An increase in household incomes
An announcement of a study that shows the health benefits of eating strawberries
questions.explanation: Strike reduces labor supply → higher input costs shift supply left. Others affect demand or are movement along supply.

questions.question: Assume that good X is a normal good. Which of the following helps to explain why a decrease in the price of good X increases the quantity demanded of good X?
options: Good X becomes relatively less expensive than its substitutes, so consumers buy more of good X and fewer of the substitutes.
The marginal utility of consuming good X increases as more of good X is consumed.
The lower price of good X decreases the marginal utility per dollar; therefore, consumers buy more of good X.
The demand curve for good X shifts to the left.
The supply curve for good X shifts to the right
questions.explanation: Substitution effect: lower price makes good X relatively cheaper than substitutes, increasing quantity demanded.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is necessary for productive efficiency?
options: The firm is producing at the point where the marginal product of labor is greater than the average product of labor.
The firm is producing a given level of output with a least-cost combination of inputs.
Consumer surplus is minimized.
There are external costs.
There is no government regulation.
questions.explanation: Productive efficiency means producing at lowest possible cost (min ATC or optimal input mix).

scoreMessages.90: Mastery of demand/supply interactions, expectations, and good classifications.
scoreMessages.70: Solid grasp; review effects of tastes, expectations, and income changes.
scoreMessages.50: Basic understanding; focus on how expectations shift demand/supply and income elasticity.
scoreMessages.0: Review: demand vs. quantity demanded, supply vs. quantity supplied, and inferior/normal goods.
